title: Long Range Planning—A Kaleidoscopic View
items.abstract: <jats:p> In recent years, corporate planning of a formal nature has expanded markedly. Surveys by the Stanford Research Institute, Business Week magazine, the National Industrial Conference Board, and the American Management Association disclose an increasing number of large firms adopting more formalized planning. This increase has been especially marked in the past five years, with the last several years particularly productive of papers on the applications of “scientific” approaches to corporate long-range planning. But organized planning has not always had such support. </jats:p>

title: Prediction and Feedback in Business Planning
items.abstract: <jats:p> This paper is concerned with how prediction and feed-back fit into business planning. The principal consideration is the integration and interrelation of these three concepts, rather than their separate development. </jats:p>

title: The Corporate Planning Process
items.abstract: <jats:p> There is something of a paradox in our use of the word planning. On the one hand, there is widespread agreement that it means looking ahead and is a desirable endeavor. On the other hand, there is considerable confusion concerning just what is implied by the word, and disagreement as to the extent to which planning is a distinctive activity or simply an ordinary aspect of almost everything we do. Thus, we find wide differences and contradictions in the use of the same planning terms, or the assumption they will mean the same thing to different people. Why this confusion and frequent contradiction? </jats:p>

title: Joint Optimization of Long-Range Planning and Short-Range Programming
items.abstract: <jats:p> The system of production planning and control described in this paper was devised as a means of stabilizing the inventory level of a ceramics firm that manufactures refractory heat-resistant products such as those used in the linings of blast furnaces. </jats:p>
